p: Acute hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection becomes chronic in most cases (55–85%) [ 1]. Chronic infection can either lead to mild illness or develop into liver cirrhosis, liver failure and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), out of 100 people infected with HCV, around 60–70 will develop chronic liver disease, 5 to 20 will develop cirrhosis in a period ranging from 20 to 30 years and 1 to 5 people will die from the consequences of cirrhosis or HCC [ 2].
